subject_terms_3: Force 136 (Guerilla movement) 1942-1945 Japanese occupation Tan, Chong Tee
physical_appearance: This is a handwritten note document. It is written in light blue ink, on a piece of paper with red printed outline. There is some inscription on the top right corner of the document. There are three staple marks along the right hand side of the document. The document is folded and slightly torn, especially along the edges.
sgcool_label_text:
These notes belong to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

Lee Shao Meng was the wife of Tan Chong Tee and was also involved in the war resistance movement in Malaya against the Japanese.
title_text: Lee Shao Meng Collection Administrative Notes on How to Develop A Overseas Party  ?????
